10.title: Out on a Limb
10.author: by Gary Kopervas.
notes: Summary: A sheep explains why it wears a face mask.

28.title: Why Mothers Get Gray

notes: (Moments We'd Like to Live Over)

30.title: Out Our Way
30.author: J
30.series: June 30, 1927) "We Hope We Get to Heaven Cuz We've Had a Little Taste"
30.appears_in: R. Williams. p. 133 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Three boys are fishing and talking about girls.

31.title: Out Our Way
31.author: J
31.appears_in: R. Williams. p. 133 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: (Born Thirty Years Too Soon)

32.title: Out Our Way
32.author: J
32.appears_in: R. Williams. p. 133 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Oldtimers complain about modern machines.

33.title: Out Our Way
33.author: J
notes: Summary: An assistant foreman is in the hospital, and his temporary replacement gives generously to the fund to send flowers.

34.title: Out Our Way

35.title: Out Our Way
35.author: J
notes: Summary: Branding calves isn't painful if you get them laughing; averted eyes of women on fence suggest pain is still present.

36.title: Out Our Way
36.author: J
notes: Summary: Everybody's been falling over the fence that's supposed to protect the newly planted lawn.

37.title: Out Our Way
37.author: J
37.series: Apr. 19, 1948) "A Son of Mine! Scalped Sod He Brings!"*
notes: Summary: Sent to the vacant lot to get sod for the lawn, he finds other people have taken the first layer so he brings a wheelbarrow full of the second layer.
(Why Mothers Get Gray).

38.title: Out Our Way
38.author: J
notes: Summary: Taking some ether, i.e., relaxed posture, reading comics and magazines while dishwashing, means they won't have such horrible memories of it.

39.title: Out Our Way
39.author: J
notes: Summary: In the dentist's waiting room, the patient is calm but his companions aren't comfortable.

40.title: Out Our Way
40.author: J
40.series: May 5, 1949) "You Poke th' Horse with th Pole"*
notes: (Born Thirty Years Too Soon)
Summary: Boys on top of a covered bridge plan to drop a catfish through the roof and down the neck of a dozing buggy driver, then make a getaway.

41.title: Out Our Way
41.author: J
41.appears_in: R. Williams. p. 74 in Cowboys Out Our Way (New York : Scribner, 1951).
notes: Summary: The Chinese cook is practicing horsemanship before a forty-mile ride.

42.title: Out Our Way
42.author: J
42.appears_in: R. Williams. p. 75 in Cowboys Out Our Way (New York : Scribner, 1951).
notes: Summary: The Chinese cook is in pain from his ride, and the cowboys have him tied across the saddle.

43.title: Out Our Way
43.author: J
43.appears_in: R. Williams. p. 75 in Cowboys Out Our Way (New York : Scribner, 1951).
notes: Summary: The Chinese cook is being moved from one camp to another in a stretcher hung between two horses.

44.title: Out Our Way
44.author: J
notes: Summary: The Chinese cook makes good grub, but the thought of getting him back home ruins the appetite.

45.title: Out Our Way
45.author: J
notes: Summary: The Chinese cook says he enjoyed the trip, and the cowboys wonder what kind of nut philosophy he has since the trip nearly killed him.

46.title: Out Our Way
46.author: J
46.series: July 31, 1950) "Look What I Get Done While I Ain't Even Here!"*
notes: (Why Mothers Get Gray)
Summary: He has attached a reel of pictures to the push mower, belted to the lower roller. Passers-by are each expected to mow enough lawn to see all the pictures.

47.title: Out Our Way
47.author: J
notes: Summary: A man is staggering down the street and big brother think's he's a drunk, but the Worry Wart says he's only walking a busybody wire-haired dog.

48.title: Out Our Way
48.author: J
notes: Summary: A worker sneaks a smoke by sticking his head in the smoke of his machine; the machine blows smoke rings.

49.title: Out Our Way
49.author: J
notes: Summary: Three boys are camping out, and in the morning one of them is up a tree because there was a pebble under him on the ground.

50.title: Out Our Way
50.author: [No author]
50.series: Sept. 2, 1951?) "Don't Hurry on Account of Us, Elt"*
notes: (Heroes are Made, Not Born)
Summary: It'll take him an hour and a half to mow the lawn, but his friends will wait.

51.title: Out Our Way
51.author: J
51.series: Oct. 22, 1951) "That's No Gag about th' Barefoot Kid with a Pinhook Ketchin' More Fish than the Expert!"*
notes: (Why Mothers Get Gray).
Setting: A restaurant, where the son has ordered something that looks better than what the father has.

52.title: Out Our Way
52.author: J
notes: Summary: The bike is nicely painted red, but the side of the garage shows considerable evidence of the process.

53.title: Out Our Way
53.author: J
notes: Summary: A foot foreman is promoted to a desk job, but he's still using his pockets for a desk.

54.title: Out Our Way
54.author: J
notes: Summary: A lawnmower rigged with a pan lid and a coil of wire gets passers-by to try mowing his lawn out of curiousity.

55.title: Out Our Way
55.author: J
notes: Summary: The Bull of the Woods has to put up with leaners pushing his desk around.

56.title: Out Our Way
56.author: J
56.series: June 16, 1953) "Put a Lid On It Till It's Done!"*
notes: (When You'd Love to Live Forever)
Summary: Dad's cooking fish over a campfire, and the rest of the family is tortured with hunger.

57.title: Out Our Way
57.author: J
notes: Summary: They're reading Julius Caesar in the bunkhouse.

58.title: Out Our Way
58.author: J
notes: (Heroes Are Made, Not Born)
Summary: The little dog on the leash eyes the fire hydrant, out of reach over the shoveled show.

59.title: Out Our Way
59.author: J
59.series: Apr. 6, 1954) "I Tell You We're at th' Worst Age of Life"*
notes: (Heroes are Made, Not Born)
Summary: One boy begins to lament all the things they're too young or too old for, and the others stop him before only birdwatching is left.

60.title: Out Our Way
60.author: J
notes: Summary: He's trying to invent a carton that will shrink as the contents are used, and is experimenting with toy balloons, corn flakes, soap powder, coffee, and a meat grinder.

61.title: Out Our Way
61.author: J
notes: Summary: The Worry Wart is drinking from an outdoor faucet, and water seems to be streaming from the back of his head; big brother is concerned he'll rinse out what brain he has.

62.title: Out Our Way
62.author: J
notes: Summary: The fire tower has reported smoke; the boys complain that you get caught smoking quicker in the wilderness than at home.

63.title: Out Our Way
63.author: J
notes: Summary: The family's complaining that cars and houses are getting smaller while corn flake and other cartons are getting bigger.

64.title: Out Our Way
64.author: J
notes: (Life's Longest Minute)
Summary: A weaving bicyclist with a guitar, not looking where he's going, is on an apparent collision course with a pedestrian shopper.

65.title: Out Our Way
65.author: J
notes: (Life's Longest Minute)
Summary: A bicyclist is on a collision path with a pedestrian, and he's not looking where he's going. He has a guitar, she has groceries.

66.title: Out Our Way
66.author: J
notes: Summary: The whole family uses the same coat hook, though there are five vacant ones in the closet.

67.title: Out Our Way
67.author: J
67.series: Aug. 22, 1955) "Good Night! A Amazon fer a Sister!"*
notes: Summary: There's missing groceries, so sis hauls the South Seas expedition out of the water by its anchor rope.

68.title: Out Our Way
68.author: J
notes: Summary: Four outfits were buying him drinks, so the new cook can't walk, but they've hired him and dragged him out to the ranch.

69.title: Out Our Way
69.author: J
69.series: Dec. 24, 1955) "Forgot about th' Whiskers and Fur"*
notes: (Heroes are Made, not Born)
Summary: Dad sets himself afire smoking in his Santa suit, and is found lying under the outdoor faucet.

70.title: Out Our Way
70.author: J
70.series: Dec. 4, 1956?) "A Dachshund Can Squeeze Thru a Awful Small Hole, But Don't Ask Me to Pull Him Thru the Same Hole Folded!"*
notes: (Heroes Are Made, Not Born)
Summary: A dog on a leash has run through a culvert.
The final digit of the year in the copyright line is indistinct.

71.title: Out Our Way
71.author: J
notes: Summary: The boss is under ether in the hospital, but the foremen at the shop need to talk to him anyhow.

72.title: Out Our Way
72.author: J
notes: Summary: The Worry Wart leaves the kitchen after making sandwiches, wishing he could write so he could leave a note saying he'd been there.

73.title: Out Our Way
73.author: [No author]
73.series: Oct. 11, 1960) "This Man-Power Fire Department is Obsolete

contents.author: J.R. Williams.
contents.title: We Need Horses!"* (Out Our Way, Oct. 11, 1960)

notes: (Born Fifty Years Too Soon)
Summary: An array of men is lying in the road, the fire-engine having run them over as they pulled it downhill.

74.title: Out Our Way
74.author: Neg Cochran.
74.series: Oct. 26, 1960) "I Simply Can't Face Mulligan Stew or Hobo's Hash Any More!"*
notes: (Grampaw)
Summary: Grampaw has decided to cook, and it's too late to suggest eating out.

75.title: Out Our Way
75.author: J
75.series: Dec. 13, 1960) "They're Lucky I Didn't Drop 'Em on the Hard Stone!"*
notes: (Heroes are Made, Not Born)
Summary: Dad's arms are paralyzed from carrying heavy children.

76.title: Out Our Way
76.author: Neg Cochran.
notes: Summary: His research on drought-resistant grass doesn't impress his friends, who would prefer not to have a better lawn and the work that comes with it.

77.title: Out Our Way
77.author: New Cochran.
77.series: May 11, 1961) "When Did You Get the New Hearing Aid?"*
notes: (Grampaw)
Summary: Gramps has a new pocket radio with an earphone, and is getting ribbed about it.

78.title: Out Our Way
78.author: Neg Cochran.
78.series: May 18, 1961) "The Classic Pose of the Hunter"*
notes: (The Worry Wart)
Summary: The Wart is trying to get his dog to be a pointer.

79.title: Out Our Way
79.author: J
notes: Summary: Wes's horse steps in a prairie dog hole and doesn't get hurt.

80.title: Out Our Way
80.author: Neg Cochran.
80.series: Oct. 28, 1961) "I Decided to Paint My Bike with it Yesterday!"*
notes: (Heroes are Made, Not Born)
Summary: The can of paint designated for the kitchen chairs turns up empty.

81.title: Out Our Way
81.author: J
81.series: Feb. 8, 1962) "When I Git That Lawn Chair Down to Her House, She'll Tell Me to Leave it an' We'll Never Own It Again"*
notes: (Why Mothers Get Gray)
Summary: The sleeping nephew and niece are in the wheeled chair ready to be rolled home.

82.title: Out Our Way
82.author: J
notes: Summary: The cowboys with the stick and the pliers can't decide which is the porcupine and which is the dog.

83.title: Out Our Way
83.author: J
notes: Summary: Wes has been bounced out into a gully and points the camera at clouds while a herd of deer runs alongside the car.

84.title: Out Our Way
84.author: J
84.series: May 10, 1962) "I'd Never Trot a High Steppin' Horse Through That Thing!"*
notes: (Born Fifty Years Too Soon)
Summary: Boys on the riverbank see the four legs of a horse sticking through the bottom of a bridge.

85.title: Out Our Way
85.author: J
85.series: Aug. 21, 1963) "Well, I Hope It Doesn't Work!"*
notes: (Why Mothers Get Gray)

Summary: The boy has combined a wagon and a push mower in such a way that a wheel of the wagon should turn the drive wheel of the mower, and the mower should then cut the tall grass off several inches above the ground, "them babies that duck when th' mower goes over 'em, then pop right up again!" His mother figures he's then going to charge her twice for mowing the lawn.

86.title: Out Our Way
86.author: Neg Cochran.
86.series: Nov. 14, 1963) "From Me She Expects Stammering and Faltering, but One Stutter Out of Him is Enough to Make Her Suspicious!"*
notes: (Heroes are Made, Not Born)
Summary: The boys are going bowling but mother is supposed to think they're going to the library.

87.title: Out Our Way
87.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: The Major announces that he's already in the contest, and reminisces about having lectured to a secret meeting of chefs in Paris.

88.title: Out Our Way
88.author: J
88.series: Mar. 30, 1964) "He Soaks Up a Barrel of Rain"*
notes: (Why Mothers Get Gray)
Summary: It's raining, and he tried to walk the dog tucked under the slicker, but she caught him at it.

89.title: Out Our Way
89.author: J
notes: Summary: The boys are in the barn trying to sleep in the hay, dealing with humps and hollows.

90.title: Out Our Way
90.author: Neg Cochran.
90.series: July 18, 1964) "I'll Have My Yaks When She Finds Out Who Actually Turned On the Water"*
notes: (Heroes are Made, not Born)
Summary: Concerns a lawn sprinkler under a lawn chair.

91.title: Out Our Way
91.author: J
notes: Summary: The sight of the lawnmower crippled him, but his friends are reluctant to help him fake the charleyhorse.

92.title: Out Our Way
92.author: J
92.series: Dec. 2, 1964) "Yes, it Smells Delicious From Away In Here Even"*
notes: (Heroes are Made, Not Born)
Summary: Dad was on K.P. in the army a lot, so he's confident about making a tray to take up to Ma.

93.title: Out Our Way
93.author: J
93.series: Jan. 7, 1965) "I Just Was Out Tryin' Out My New Bike!"*
notes: (Why Mothers Get Gray)
Summary: The sidewalk has been cleared of snow in a odd pattern.

94.title: Out Our Way
94.author: J
94.series: Jan. 18, 1965) "My Bike Sounds Like a Turkey Gobblin' Ever Since He First Used It!"*
notes: (Born Forty Years Too Soon)
Summary: His garage is fourteen blocks from home so he has to use a bicycle to get to it, and people yell at him about the noise.

95.title: Out Our Way
95.author: Neg Cochran.
notes: Summary: The bookworm wants to practice his part in the play ("Friends, Romans, countrymen"), the others want to fly kites.

96.title: Out Our Way
96.author: J
notes: Summary: One of the men has come over from the bunkhouse in a blizzard in his longjohns, to ask Cooky what to do for a bad cold.

97.title: Out Our Way
97.author: Neg Cochran.
97.series: Mar. 18, 1965) "Your Brother Made a Bet with Him that Not One Bird Would Land On It All Day!"*
notes: (Life's Longest Minute)
Summary: Grampaw has caught the brother popping paper bags to keep birds away from the bird feeder.

98.title: Out Our Way
98.author: J
notes: Summary: A pair of killer/bank robbers are fleeing on bicycles from a posse; they pass up the chance to steal horses because then they'd really be in trouble.

99.title: Out Our Way
99.author: [No author]
99.series: May 24, 1965) "Never Ridicule Elderly People. You'll Be There Some Day!"*
notes: (Born Forty Years Too Soon)
Summary: Boys with shinny sticks poke fun at a passing couple of golfers. He is carrying two golf bags, and she has none.

100.title: Out Our Way
100.author: J
100.series: June 7, 1965) "Anywhere, Just So We Get Him"*
notes: (Why Mothers Get Gray)
Summary: He has sculpted a cartoon face into the front lawn with the mower, and mother and sister are out looking for him.

101.title: Out Our Way
101.author: J
notes: Summary: The Bull of the Woods has covered his desk with advertising gadgets to keep people from leaning on it, but it isn't working.

102.title: Out Our Way
102.author: Neg Cochran.
102.series: Oct. 2, 1965) "I Play This Game for Exercise!"*
notes: (Grampaw)
Summary: Grampaw doesn't want to ride in the golf cart and get a bay window.

103.title: Out Our Way
103.author: J
notes: Summary: A progression is described, in which not being helpful and taking in the milk bottles for the cook leads to one's becoming the cook.

104.title: Out Our Way
104.author: Neg Cochran.
104.series: Oct. 26, 1965) "I Threw Up My Hand to Protect My Face and He Belted Me on the Glove"*
notes: (The Worry Wart)
Summary: The boys are boxing with a pair of gloves between them. The Wart had to defend himself from a haymaker and got a black eye.

105.title: Out Our Way
105.author: J
105.series: Nov. 9, 1965) "I've Stunted my Growth Enough, Packin' Snoozers Home from Movies!"*
notes: (Why Mothers Get Gray)
Summary: The bicycle has a plank tied to it.

106.title: Out Our Way
106.author: Neg Cochran.
notes: Summary: A worker has stumped a "lesser boss," and the big boss is waiting his turn.

107.title: Out Our Way
107.author: Neg Cochran.
notes: Summary: The guys are leaving for golf, which is no crazier than ice fishing; they're dressed for the weather and they'll use a red ball to see it in the snow.

108.title: Out Our Way
108.author: Neg Cochran.
108.series: Mar. 30, 1968) "They Must Have Re-zoned this Neighborhood for High-Rise Bird Houses!"*
notes: (Grampaw)
Summary: Fun is poked at Grampaw's new birdhouse.

109.title: Out Our Way
109.author: Neg Cochran.
109.series: Apr. 25, 1968) "From Now On We Leave That Mudlark Home in Wet Weather"*
notes: (Why Mothers Get Gray)
Summary: The dog took off and now they're both covered with mud.

110.title: Out Our Way
110.author: Neg Cochran.
110.series: July 25, 1968) "That's What I Told Tom when he Called to Find out What Time He Should Meet You at the Golf Course in the Morning"*
notes: (Heroes are Made, not Born)
Summary: He's turning in early, saying he's going to get busy in the morning at the list of jobs she wants done.

111.title: Out Our Way
111.author: Neg E
notes: Summary: The camp cook will only fry the fish if the fishermen clean them first.

112.title: Out Our Way
112.author: Neg Cochran.
notes: Summary: The boy who collected his green apples in baskets gets a chance to sell them; he gets greenbacks and the others just get green around the gills: "You're more likely to get the nod from Lady Luck if you're willing to give her an assist."
Key words: Money, stomach aches. Call no.: PN6726f.B55 "luck"

113.title: Out Our Way
113.author: Neg Cochran.
notes: Summary: The men are cooking breakfast, and it's taking a long time because they're flipping things in the air from their frying pans.

114.title: Out Our Way
114.author: Neg Cochran.
notes: Summary: Because of the rise in the cost of living, the son posts a price list for the jobs he does; the mother agrees about the inflationary times and proposes her own list.

115.title: Out Our Way
115.author: Neg Cochran.
notes: (The Worry Wart)
Summary: The Worry Wart is painting a landscape, and has taped up some cotton to look at when he paints the clouds.

116.title: Out Our Way
116.author: Neg Cochran.
notes: Summary: The dog gets to clean up the spilled milk, and the Dad gets a sponge mop to clean up after the dog.

117.title: Out Our Way
117.author: Neg Cochran.
notes: Summary: Though they run the risk of being accused of stalling, the painting crew has smuggled a television set into the room to watch golf.

118.title: Out Our Way
118.author: Neg Cochran.
notes: Summary: The only way to get your room painted is to hound Pa and Jimmy until they get sick of you.

119.title: Out Our Way
119.author: Neg Cochran.
notes: Summary: The boy's getting washed and the dog's trying to help make the mother look like a heartless bully.

120.title: Out Our Way
120.author: by Neg Cochran.
notes: Summary: Mother gets the change from the groceries plus other things from the pocket: golf tee, paper clip, button, rubber bands and lint.

121.title: Out Our Way
121.author: Neg Cochran.
121.series: Jan. 24, 1972) "He Needs Discouragin', an' I'm Here to See That He Gets It!"*
notes: (Grampaw)
Summary: Grampaw is protecting his bird feeder from a cat, with a pea shooter.

122.title: Out Our Way
122.author: Neg Cochran.
notes: Summary: Elwood gets put on the late shift, and since he's a golf nut he likes it.

123.title: Out Our Way
123.author: Neg Cochran.
notes: (Heroes are Made, Not Born)
Summary: The the boys have sorted themselves into management and labor and gone into business with a snow blower.

124.title: Out Our Way
124.author: Neg Cochran.
124.series: Feb. 7, 1973) "It Calls for Too Much Exertion"*
notes: (When You'd Love To Live Forever)
Summary: There's too much snow for Pa and Grandpa to deal with, Ma's going to call a neighbor boy, and the men settle in to smoke and read the paper.

146.heading: Out Our Way--Miscellanea.
146.title: "Reining In the Parade"
146.author: R
146.appears_in: C. Harvey. p. 99-103 in The Comics Journal, no. 221 (Mar. 2000).
notes: (Comicopia)

Essay on the continuing of comic strips after the death of their creators, with special attention to Peanuts and Pogo, and paragraphs on the situations with Bringing Up Father, Blondie, Gasoline Alley, Barnaby, Popeye, Out Our Way (The Willets), Snuffy Smith (Barney Google), Moon Mullins, and Annie (Little Orphan Annie).
